column2: New Luntz focus group of vaccine-hesitant Republicans: No more Fauci please
column5: If the headline sounds familiar itâ€™s because the last focus group Luntz did with GOPers who are iffy on the vaccine also found them chilly to Fauci. Which you would think would matter to Team Biden since Republicans are among the demographics who are least likely to get vaccinated. If the pro-vax message isnâ€™t getting through because of hostility to the messenger then change the messenger. But they just keep on running him out there for the cameras because Democrats love him never mind that Democrats overwhelmingly are already sold on getting vaccinated. At some point polling like this has to the matter to the feds leading the vaccination PR effort right? Earlier this month YouGov found Fauci earning sky-high trust among Democrats only & struggling among all other groups (R's independents etc). He is no longer an effective public health messenger for much of the country yet he remains ubiquitous in that role. pic.twitter.com/ziIODBpIXB â€” Guy Benson (@guypbenson) April 18 2021  If they wonâ€™t take the pollstersâ€™ word for it will they take Luntzâ€™s? â€œThe further we go into the vaccination process the more passionate the hesitancy isâ€ Luntz said after the session. â€œIf youâ€™ve refused to take the vaccine this long itâ€™s going to be hard to switch you.â€â€¦ Unlike a similar focus group five weeks ago when most participants told Luntz and Frieden that the session persuaded them to get shots attendees Sunday said they were swayed only moderately by doctorsâ€™ urging â€” or not moved at allâ€¦ One figure was roundly panned at the focus group: Anthony S. Fauci director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Every participant said they preferred hearing from politicians over the medical expert who has been pilloried by conservative media for months over his coronavirus warnings. â€œThe data have shown that unfortunately Dr. Fauci has been politicized and we need different messengers because even the right messages coming from the wrong messengers arenâ€™t always helpfulâ€ Castrucci said noting his foundationâ€™s polling found Americans trust their personal doctors more than the governmentâ€™s top infectious-disease doctor. Interestingly the â€œpauseâ€ on the Johnson & Johnson vaccine didnâ€™t seem to faze the participants on Luntzâ€™s panel. What fazed them was the head of Pfizer recently speculating that people would need a third shot as a booster at some point this fall. Go figure that those who are reluctant to get one or two shots would be put off by the idea of getting three. â€œI feel like this is not going to end. I mean weâ€™re just going to be shot up and shot up and shot upâ€ said one. What Luntz told WaPo about vaccine hesitancy getting more stubborn among the holdouts as the pool of unvaccinated Americans shrinks may be starting to show up in the data. Daily total = to last Tues down from April 7 Data: https://t.co/0eOgSRgh2J pic.twitter.com/m2yLMumExV â€” Drew Armstrong (@ArmstrongDrew) April 21 2021  The downward turn began right around the time that J&J was paused due to blood-clot fears. Hmmmm. Nate Silver noted last night that we did 1.8 million shots yesterday versus 2.5 million the Tuesday before which also seems like a bad sign. Between the new jitters about side effects and the fact that weâ€™re gradually exhausting the supply of Americans who are gung ho to get vaxxed we may already be approaching the proverbial â€œwall.â€ And if we are thatâ€™s not great. Just 26 percent have been fully vaccinated 40 percent partly. Assuming that everyone whoâ€™s already had one shot ends up getting both (which doesnâ€™t always happen) having just 40 percent of the population immunized probably isnâ€™t going to get us to herd immunity. Even if we guesstimate that another 25 percent of Americans already have natural immunity from being infected and further that no one in that group overlaps with the vaccinated group (which of course isnâ€™t true) 65 percent total immunity also is short of scientistsâ€™ best guesses of what weâ€™ll need in order to slow the spread to a trickle. Some believe weâ€™ll have to have upwards of 85 percent vaxxed in order to do that. Could we hit that target once children are eligible to be vaccinated? Itâ€™s hard to believe that a parent whoâ€™s skeptical about being vaccinated themselves would allow their child to take the risk. And even some parents who are pro-vax for themselves may be anti-vax when it comes to their kids reasoning that the risk of a child suffering a serious illness from infection is so small that itâ€™s not worth exposing them to the risk of vaccine side effects in order to mitigate it. All of which is to say how do we reach the remainder of the population now that weâ€™re through the group that was eager to be vaccinated? Experts think itâ€™s time to move from the â€œFauci begging everyone to get the shot 12 times a day on TVâ€ stage to the concierge stage in which case maybe the White Houseâ€™s messaging problem with Fauci is already basically solved. They donâ€™t need one ubiquitous national spokesman anymore. They need hundreds of thousands of local spokesmen â€” namely doctors since people who are reluctant to get vaxxed tend to say theyâ€™d be more likely to do so if their own physician recommended it. The problem is how to get the product into the hands of individual doctors particularly ones in far-flung rural places who might not have many patients. Yet having individual doctors administer the vaccine poses a logistical challenge for pharmaceutical companies and the Biden administration which ships doses to states in large quantities. One vaccine maker Pfizer-BioNTech ships 1170 doses in a single pallet; the other Moderna ships packets of 10 vials containing 100 doses. Those amounts are unsuitable for doctorsâ€™ offices and smaller settings which have been the focus of Alabamaâ€™s vaccination effort. Dr. Harris said the vaccine packaging â€œhas been disastrous for us.â€ Private employers may be the next pressure point. The private sector is eager to jump in and help educate employees â€” and even administer vaccines said Kathryn Wylde the president of the Partnership for New York City the cityâ€™s leading business organization. Either way weâ€™re shifting from eager recipients coming to the vaccine to the vaccine being brought to holdouts where they work and receive medical care. So maybe Fauci doesnâ€™t matter so much anymore. One nagging issue with the concierge approach though: What to do about young adults who are less likely to seek/need care at a doctorâ€™s office and therefore may not be particularly reachable through their personal physicians? Theyâ€™re one of the biggest vaccine-holdout groups in the population because of the low risk of serious illness that COVID presents to them. If you canâ€™t get them vaxxed at the doctor how do you do it? Maybe Israelâ€™s â€œa shot for a shotâ€ gimmick would work. Itâ€™s time for the FDA to get creative. Hereâ€™s Biden celebrating a milestone. Remember the original underwhelming â€œ100 million shots in 100 daysâ€ target? Weâ€™ve done 200 million in 93. Fantastic.
